title: 111_hr1558
content: The Act may be cited as the "Preexisting Condition Patient Protection Act of 2009". The Congress finds that millions of Americans were uninsured or underinsured in 2007, with a significant number having chronic conditions. Many states allow insurance companies to deny coverage for preexisting conditions. Additionally, over 26 million people were enrolled in private health plans in 2007 under HIPAA. The Insurance Portability and Accountability Act of 1996 (HIPAA) does not protect individuals against pre-existing condition exclusions or waiting periods. When there is a 63-day gap in insurance coverage, pre-existing condition exclusions can be imposed on them when they get a new health insurance policy. Eliminating pre-existing condition exclusions for all is crucial for ensuring access to healthcare. A majority of Americans support the Federal Government requiring health insurance companies to cover anyone who applies, even with a prior illness. SEC. 3. AMENDMENTS RELATING TO PREEXISTING CONDITION EXCLUSIONS UNDER GROUP HEALTH PLANS. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 eliminate preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans and health insurance coverage. This includes prohibiting preexisting condition exclusions and affiliation periods for coverage through health maintenance organizations. Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 eliminate preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans and health insurance coverage, including affiliation periods for coverage through health maintenance organizations. The term 'affiliation period' refers to the period before health insurance coverage becomes effective. Subsections (c), (d), (e), and (g) are removed, and subsection (f) is redesignated as subsection (c). Amendments to the Public Health Service Act eliminate preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans and health insurance coverage. This includes the prohibition of affiliation periods for coverage through health maintenance organizations. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act eliminate preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans and health insurance coverage. This includes removing affiliation periods for coverage through health maintenance organizations. The term 'affiliation period' refers to the waiting period before health insurance coverage becomes effective. Additionally, technical amendments related to employer size are made in Section 2711 of the Act. Amendments to the Public Health Service Act remove preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans and insurance coverage, including eliminating affiliation periods for coverage through health maintenance organizations. Technical changes related to employer size are made in Section 2711 of the Act by removing references to "small" employers. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 eliminate preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans, including removing references to "small" employers. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 remove preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans by striking certain subsections and redesignating others. The amendments eliminate preexisting condition exclusions for group health plans, with an effective date for plan years after the 12th month following enactment. Special rules apply for group health plans under collective bargaining agreements. The termination of collective bargaining agreements related to the plan is determined without considering any extensions agreed upon after the enactment of this Act or after the 12th calendar month following the enactment. Plan amendments made to conform to new requirements added by this Act do not constitute a termination of the collective bargaining agreement. SEC. 4 prohibits preexisting condition exclusions in individual health insurance coverage. Section 2741 of the Public Health Service Act is amended to prohibit preexisting condition exclusions in individual health insurance coverage for eligible individuals. The amendments also specify that no individual can be declined coverage or denied enrollment, and no preexisting condition exclusions can be imposed. The amendments made by this section regarding preexisting condition exclusions in individual health insurance coverage will take effect in the individual market 12 months after the enactment of this Act. SEC. 5. TRANSPARENCY IN CLAIMS DATA. The Secretary of Health and Human Services must submit a report to Congress within 2 years of this Act's enactment on the impact of the Act on health benefits coverage. The report may include data on claims experience and enrollee information from group health plans and health insurance issuers. The Secretary may request data on claims experience and enrollee information from group health plans and health insurance issuers, including the composition of enrollees. Failure to provide requested data may be subject to enforcement under the Public Health Service Act. GAO Report: Within 1 year of this Act's enactment, the Comptroller General must report to Congress on how this Act and other federal laws impact reducing uninsured and underinsured individuals in group and individual health insurance markets, as well as coverage affordability.
